Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Workshops on Cultural Production in the Digital Age

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the past, the relative scarcity of production resources and capacities meant that media could offer only narrow channels by which citizens could engage in cultural production. That public discourse increasingly came to resemble those narrow channels, in sometimes problematic ways. Today, the ever increasing ubiquity of personal computers, content production software, and mobile devices, the penetration of broadband internet connections both in the United States and across the post-industrial world, and the rise of server-side applications for circulating content to vast social information networks, all have forced researchers to reconsider this relationship between cultural production and public discourse.

This project will assemble a small group of international faculty and graduate students from a mix of disciplinary backgrounds who are already asking compelling questions in this area, along with technology designers whose tools intervene in current cultural production practices. This group will establish a virtual research group for one year, anchored by face-to-face meetings at either end, in order to develop vital, inter-disciplinary tools for better understanding the interplay of digital technologies and cultural production in contemporary social contexts.

We aim to meet five objectives:
1) Foster interdisciplinary dialogue on issues of cultural production and its relationship to digital technology, socio-technical networks, and cultures; 2) map core areas of research and identify collaborative opportunities and existing research gaps; 3) Envision alternative information platforms premised on the insights gained in the workshop, designed both to serve and interrogate public expression on a societal scale; 4) produce a public, online resource that will draw together a wider set of scholars similarly engaged in these questions; and, 5) facilitate graduate student training, by including graduate students with relevant dissertation projects.

The project will contribute to science and technology studies, games studies, and other social science inquiry into digital cultural production. The project's broader impact will include the development of theoretical contributions and proposals for future empirical research. Results will be available online, presented at professional meetings, submitted to selected journals, such as New Media and Society, The Information Society, and Convergence, and published in an edited book.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the past, the relative scarcity of production resources and capacities meant that media could offer only narrow channels by which citizens could engage in cultural production. That public discourse increasingly came to resemble those narrow channels, sometimes in problematic ways. Today, the ever increasing availability of personal computers, content production software, and mobile devices, the penetration of broadband internet connections both in the United States and across the post-industrial world, and the rise of social media platforms for circulating content to vast interpersonal and public networks – all of these together have forced researchers to reconsider this relationship between cultural production, new media technologies, and public discourse. These are the scholarly concerns of Culture Digitally.

With the generous support of the National Science Foundation, co-PIs Hector Postigo and Tarleton Gillespie have developed a sustained scholarly cadre called Culture Digitally. It is meant to be a gathering point for scholars who study the workings of digital society. We come from a range of fields, including Communication, Sociology, Media Studies, Science & Technology Studies, and Anthropology. But we are connected by our research interests, an emerging area of scholarship that currently lives across, or sometimes falls between, our home disciplines. It’s our sense that this emerging discussion needs more homes, be they virtual or institutional.

 In the initial proposal for NSF funding, we imagined a virtual research group for one year, anchored by face-to-face workshops at the start and finish, in order to develop vital, inter-disciplinary tools for better understanding the interplay of digital technologies and cultural production in contemporary social contexts. During that one year we would continue to interact and publish on a scholarly blog.

 These initial events were held in 2011 and 2012, and helped to identify a community of two dozen faculty and graduate students interested in continuing this work, using the community as a sounding board, and to add our research to public discussions through the blog we developed, culturedigitally.org.

 Happily, this collaboration has continued past the one year imagined and extended to meet its goals. The blog continues to flourish, and has become a magnet to new participants wanting to share their research. Between its start in July 2011 and November 2013, it has 166 posts from 45 different authors. The home page has had more than 25,000 views, the whole site has had over 108,500 views, and its most popular post has had just over 13,000 views. Select posts have also appeared on Microsoft Research's Social Media Collective, the MIT Press blog, and the academic video game blog Gamasutra, among others. Two of our posts have appeared in Salon, and three of our posts have been published as invited essays by the Journal of Broadcasting and Electronic Media. Scholarly essays that were either incubated in our workshops or on the blog has reached publication in New Media and Society; Information and Communication and Society; Journal of Communication; Communication, Culture & Critique; Digital Journalism; Ethics and Information Technology; Culture Machine; Television and New Media; Canadian Journal of Communication; communication +1; International Journal of Cultural Policy; and Public Culture.

 We have held additional meetings, piggybacked on academic conferences: one in June 2013 in London, another informal session in October 2013 in Denver.
